p.s: Description of Thermomonospora formosensis sp. nov.
Thermomonospora formosensis (for.mos'en.sis. L. adj. formosensis of Formosa [Republic of China]).
Single spores are formed on both aerial and vegetative mycelia.
Mature spores are heat sensitive, nonmotile, and globose with warty surfaces (diameter, about 1.0 Î¼m).
Colonies are usually pinkish or light orange, depending on the medium, with or without white aerial mycelium.
There is little to no soluble pigment.
Type III cell walls and pattern B whole-cell sugars.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the deoxyribonucleic acid is 72.0 mol% (as determined by the thermal denaturation method).
Dipicolinic acid is not contained in mature spores.
Cultures hydrolyze gelatin and milk, but not starch.

D-Mannitol, D-glucose, soluble starch, D-galactose, and sucrose are utilized, but D-sorbitol, L-arabinose, L-rhamnose, maltose, trehalose, lactose, i-inositol, D-xylose, D-fructose, raffinose, D-mannose, and glycerol are not utilized or are poorly utilized.
Growth occurs on media supplemented with NaCl at a concentration of 2% or less.
Strain C-36820, the type strain of T. formosensis, has been deposited in the Institute for Fermentation, Osaka, Japan, as strain IFO 14204.
Because the species description given above is based on a single strain, it also serves as the description of the type strain.
